39446063.review:
I do not understand why I like this game so much. This is clearly a mobile game that has been converted over for Steam. There seem to be some artifacts left over from this change, such as the limited item stacks. That seems like the exact thing a f2p game would have so that then they could make you buy new slots or something. I think that is also why everything seems so crazy expensive- maybe they wanted to force players to spend real $$.

But this is the paid version so those issues should be (but probably won't be) fixed. I've also had it glitch out a few times and it never created an icon for my desktop- just a blank white rectangle.

Yet for all these issues I just can't stop playing. It's an addictive puzzler, and the bears are just so cute. Pro tip- do not leave it on at night with the sound effects up b/c those sounds WILL haunt your dreams.

38385745.review:
Une tuerie, tout simplement. Pour ceux qui connaissent le jeu "2048", ils ne seront pas dépaysés, car le concept est assez proche (tout en bénéficiant d'un côté stratégique très agréable). Triple Town est ce qu'on peut appeler un casual/réflexion : chaque partie peut durer quelques minutes, ou de longues heures. Doté de graphismes adorables, et d'un concept extrêmement simple, ce jeu est avant tout une drogue qui rend extrêmement accroc. Son format fenêtré (qu'on peut passer en plein écran si l'on désire) fait qu'il peut aisément tourner alors qu'on fait autre chose en même temps : idéal pour tuer le temps !

Depuis une île principale, il est possible de choisir plusieurs navires qui embarqueront pour des cartes vides. Ces cartes, assez petites, permettent au joueur de déposer au sol divers éléments (herbe, buissons, arbres, ...) qui, lorsqu'ils sont en contact avec deux éléments identiques ou plus, se réunissent en un élément supérieur (ex : 3 herbes -> 1 buisson). La carte se remplit peut à peu d'arbres, maisons et créatures (ours, voire "ninjas"), et laisse donc bien peu de place pour tous les éléments à rajouter : il faut toujours songer à prévoir de la place en réunissant les éléments de sorte à faire des combos et autres associations. Sitôt la carte remplie, la mission est finie : retour sur l'île principale qui permet, selon la réussite de la carte précédente, d'ajouter des plantations, des tonneaux d'or et autres bonus qui améliorent le niveau.

Triple Town est de ces jeux qui captivent au point de ne plus les lâcher. En général, un joueur passera de très longues heures sur ce jeu, à faire un nombre incalculable de parties, cherchant toujours à s'améliorer dans le placement stratégique d'éléments. A mon sens, un INCONTOURNABLE du genre, qui allie la réflexion, la stratégie, la gestion, le tout de façon profondément intuitive, sans aucune action de gameplay autre que celle de cliquer pour placer les éléments sur la carte. Simpliste, enfantin, et pourtant extrêmement amusant. En plus d'être adorable, coloré et accessible à tous, ce jeu devient aussi difficile que le joueur devient bon.

Une merveille, donc, que je conseille fortement pour s'amuser en toute simplicité. Attention tout de même au côté casual qui finit par être rapidement chronophage si on ne se surveille pas. Il suffit de regarder le nombre d'heures passées sur ce jeu par ceux qui ont rédigé une critique pour s'en faire une idée (personnellement, j'ai joué à ce jeu sur GOG durant des années : ceci explique mon faible temps de jeu sur la version Steam acquise via un Bundle).

38254867.review:
昔日Facebook上相互積分較勁的[strike]傷腦[/strike]趣味小品，
如今在Steam上的版本卻是全然不同的系統介面。
不再需要控制步數，操作上顯得更直觀。

現在可以在尋常的諸多小關卡中、和家園系統間任意切換，
經由關卡中合成進化來獲取更多的增築耗材，
返回家園，能升級設施，並以關卡積分為食，產出對關卡有助益的道具，彼此能相輔相成。

你將不再受限一次只能進行一場奮戰，
因此便能令資源流通，大大提升關卡存活率。


[h1]放置千萬冷靜!最好給自己留條後路 [/h1]

在每一場奮戰中，要活得久，除了可以選擇沒有熊出沒的關卡外，
仍需要盡可能的簡單化、靠邊擺放。

如果難救直接破棄也別氣餒，當作是為了主要奮戰在積存資源吧!
能省則省，尤其是資金和儲物箱，他們是扭轉局勢的關鍵，Rush一波很實用呢!

畢竟這遊戲無法回上一動作，
因為場地有限，只要誤點錯置，很容易就會打亂了計畫，因此記得擺放前要仔細想想喔:D


[h1]惡意滿點的機制[/h1]

系統似乎有些針對玩家慣性，會產生一些充滿惡意的地方。

比方你期望出現什麼的時候就偏偏沒有、
有熊的話就會是他跑來你期待的位置賣萌...

空曠的時候，又時常出現連續一堆功能強的道具只能棄置。
但其實也可能只是臉太黑的緣故(╥﹏╥)

這就是這麼款運氣比重佔大多數的遊戲。
一起來看熊賣萌吧:D

34766101.review:
Triple Town n'est clairement pas un jeu qui marquera les esprits. Cependant il reste tout a fait honnete. Il s'agit d'un petit jeu de puzzle Match 3 dont le principe ici est de construire une ville en posant des éléments capable de créer des combinaison avec quelque subtilité selon les parties (décors/taille/précense d'ennemis ou non). Le tout accompagné d'une petite dimension stratégique assez intéréssante.

L'interface est propre, le jeu est plutôt joli et le gameplay est très accessible. On pourrais repprocher l'abscence de fond sonore mais pour un jeu de ce style c'est assez anecdotique. 

Le jeu est adapté au parties rapide et chaque séance ne depassera que rarement les 30 minutes de jeu. C'est parfait pour soufffler entre deux occupations ou pour jouer dans un laps de temps assez court. 

En sois Triple Town est plutôt un bon jeu pour ce qu'il veut proposer. Il n'a la prétention de n'être qu'un petit jeu de puzzle accesible et ça tombe bien, je ne lui en demandait pas plus. Néanmoins, le prix pourra faire grincer des dents pour ce que c'est, 10€ étant un peu trop pour un jeu de ce style. Cependant, je me souvient ne l'avoir payer a peine plus de 2€ en période de solde, et à ce prix la c'est tout à fait rentable.

32876301.review:
Jogo de match 3 divertido e viciante.

A pegada do jogo é que toda vez que você combina 3 ou mais itens do mesmo tipo, uma peça de nível mais alto aparece na cidade.
Existe também os ursos que introduzem um caráter aleatório par as partidas, pois eles se movem pelo tabuleiro.

Existe o modo de jogo padrão, e alguns outros que alteram um pouco as regras, como o tamanho do tabuleiro e a frequência de alguns itens.

Além das partidas, o jogo tem uma "cidade" onde você pode colocar peças decorativas, e outras que te fornecem itens para usar nas partidas. Você consegue a maioria dos itens comprando com "coins" que você adquire jogando as partidas. Alguns itens também são obtidos durante as combinações no jogo normal.

Se você gosta desse estilo de jogo, este é muito bom para passar o tempo, e seu progresso fica salvo o tempo todo, podendo voltar a qualquer momento, e até alterar entre os modos de jogo. Porém só existe um save para cada modo.

O jogo é free para IOs e Android, porém é cheio de microtransações. O jogo no steam é uma compra única e você pode jogar ilimitadamente, e todo o conteúdo é obtido jogando.

良い部分：
サツバツとしたタイムやスコアに追われるパズルゲーが昨今に対し

ガチ高速演算パズルもストラテジーパズルも疲れるから嫌じゃ～って！人向けのカジュアルターン性RPGなパズルゲーええぞ

その問題のステージ数が数える程しかないので、悪く言えば変化に乏しいゲームって訳DESUNA

まあ1000円しないでこの内容ならまあまずまず楽しめる出来かなって感じ
ゲーム自体はおすすめ出来るし購入検討してもいいんだけど
見てくれの通りスマホゲーチックというか元がスマホ向けで開発してたのか

28576209.review: Triple town is a unique Match 3 puzzle game that requires use of spatial awareness and planning. Each turn you get a random item to place in your city, when three or more items connect they fuze into a new thing. You go from planting lowly grass to making houses and even castles which improve your score and provide a visual asthetic of people running around and talking gibberish. You also have bears and ninja bears that will block your progress and make things difficult for you. Managing all this is the key to victory, you will eventually fill your city and the game will end, but how you do will give you more things to improve your island which is a hub world you visit in between games. The game is cute and challanging and before you know it you will rack up a bunch of hours after thinking "just one more game".

23728371.review:
What is with our predisposition for match 3? What purpose does it serve our primordial lizard brains to delight us when we put three of something together and watch it disappear? Whatever the reason may be, the game industry has seized upon this weakness with terrible force, compelling us to crush candies and swap orbs and do all sorts of ridiculous things to rack up points. Triple Town would be no different, save for one additional level of complexity that adds a unique hint of progression to the formula.

Rounds in Triple Town take place on small islands, gridded off for you to set your plants and buildings on. You're given something to place, anything from a tuft of grass to a sturdy oak to an entire house, which you can put on any open square. If three of the same thing end up adjacent to each other, such as three bushes, they combine on the spot of the last one placed into the next level of thing, such as a tree. In this way you can work your way up from grass to bush to tree to house to mansion to castle and on. Most of the time you'll be placing grass but you occasionally get higher-level objects straightaway, which you can use to your advantage or store in your single storage spot for later.

There are other factors at play, such as bears you must place that move about and block your construction, or crystals that act as wildcards, combining with any two other things to complete the set. Your goal is to amass points and reach certain milestones like Settlement and City, and the simple challenge of trying to finagle everything into place is honestly enough to keep you going. You'll slowly start puzzling out how to plan your grasses ahead to get the bushes in the right places to get trees where you want, and then realize you need to plan even further for the houses that the trees become. There's a remarkable amount of planning and strategizing involved, as well as the challenges of unexpected bear or crystal appearances.

All this would make for a fine coffee-break puzzle game, at least for awhile, but there's thankfully more to it than that. As you play, you obtain special items like farms and ores that cannot be used in normal maps. In between rounds, you travel to your capital city where you can place these to grant you additional resources periodically. These resources come in the form of items that can be used during rounds to place certain clutch objects when you need them most. The capital follows the same match-3 rules as well, meaning placing your special items intelligently can yield much greater returns. Triple Town basically gives you a hub city to develop which provides resources that makes the individual puzzles easier, allowing you to earn more items to develop your hub. It's a brilliant little gameplay loop that can keep you hooked for want of one more upgrade to your city.

It's almost a perfect package, but I must admit the presentation drags it down a little. The actual feel of Triple Town is like that of a Flash game, trapped in a static windowed mode with simple vector graphics and animation. There's almost no polish to the menus or buttons, either, which makes them feel more like developer placeholders than finished products. The sound is adequate for what it is but does nothing to alleviate the otherwise cheap feel of the game. Coming off of titles like Mini Metro that manage to be simple AND stylish, Triple Town can feel a bit disappointing. Still, the core mechanics are plenty solid and the progression systems are very addictive, so if you can look past the presentation you'll have a lovely little timesink to enjoy here.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

23284601.review:
♥ Extremely addicting.

I've used this game to pass the time for just a "few" minutes yet it always turns into at least a half hour or more of playtime. It's easy to get sucked into wanting to get the highest score...build the biggest castle...snag all the achievements.

♥ Very cute.

This is one game that I don't have to worry about my parents or my pets seeing me play. If you want a family friendly game, this one absolutely fits. Even as annoying as the ninja bears are, they're still adorable. I appreciate pretty graphics! 

♥ Wonderful way to relax.

For me this game, though it can be challenging, always helps to relax me. You can play the map for just a few moments or a few hours, it's up to you how seriously you want to play the game. That is a virtue I love since I don't want to invest myself in a game all the time yet I can challenge myself if I want to. 

✘ It can be frustrating.

This game relies heavily on random items that you get and have to put on the map/level. If you get a bad combo, it can potentially end the round. You can buy items in the store however they can be expensive (with in-game coins, not real currency) and there's a limit to how many of each item you can buy per round. 

✘  There isn't diversity in level design.

The game is still cute however the maps are all pretty much the same. Though some have lakes while others have none, they can all look alike, and thus appear fairly bland. 

✘ I do wish there were maps of different sizes.

All the maps/levels are the same size, though some have less space with lakes and rivers in the way. If this game were ever updated or a sequel made, I would appreciate if there were more diversity in the size of the towns. It would be fun to have some huge, some small, etc. 

Overall this is a wonderful game and all flaws aside, I think it would make a lovely game for any gamer.

22391797.review:
===============以下是给triple town的====================
非常棒的游戏。小游戏里面最喜欢的没有之一。

===============以下是给road not taken的====================
你问我支不支持，我肯定是支持的。但是最近钱不太够，就退款了。你问我这是不是一款好游戏，我肯定的说是。
我是非常喜欢《三联镇》的，以至于知道有PC版时马上以原价购买了（一款12年的纯单机独立游戏）。然而对于这款《road not taken》我只能说这不是我玩《三联镇》时的感觉。
《三联镇》的游戏体验非常棒，学习成本很低，一切都是自然而然的，简约的元素，可靠的游戏体验保障，进入游戏很快，退出游戏成本很低，有事没事来一局，有事关了也不心疼，下次进入能马上代入，甚至是边看视频边玩游戏的好选择。而且建造村子的创意非常简约而自由。
而《road not taken》具备了太多细碎的元素，不直观，很多东西完了一个小时了完全不知道是什么。《road not
taken》采用了很重的场景式导航，进入解密现场需要先穿过村子（大约需要10秒），我觉得对于一场游戏大约20秒的游戏来说这个体验很糟心（每4~6场就要走一遍村子），这不仅使得进入游戏很慢，且打断了游戏的流畅体验。而且这4~6场是有关联的，这导致游戏的关闭成本很高昂，你下次打开需要花很多时间来回忆或推测上次的思路。再然后，这次你不能建造村子，而是和村民刷好感结婚，但是你的主角的性别是随机的，也就是说你看上了村子里一个可爱妹子，结果主角头套一掀也是个妹子，还是很丑的那种，我只能说我的内心是崩溃的。
最重要的是这是一款推箱子的游戏，通过类似限制步数的方式控制游戏进程。也就是说就好像在玩中国代理的免费手机版三联镇那样（有步数限制），非常揪心，你需要小心翼翼，绞尽脑汁去避免浪费步数，而不是直面难题。
最后说下优点：画风可爱（如果我有孩子我会买给他），谜题还算具备重玩价值（但是绝达不到传统roguelike的感觉）。

It's a fun strategy game, a different take on the Match 3 genre. You match up 3 patches a grass to make a bush(it appears where the last patch of grass was placed), 3 bushes make a tree, 3 trees make a house, 3 houses make a large house, etc. There are many other mechanics that  I don't want to spoil, and there's in-game store to buy items with in-game currency.

There's also a home island, called your Capital, where you can place industries like farms and mines like you would in the normal game, but as you score points these industries give you items. A nice little meta game. I definitely recommend Triple Town.

22141666.review:
Aaah Triple Town!

I was first introduced to this game on Android in 2012. I loved it so much I bought it for PC. The PC version has no micro-transactions, which makes it far more enjoyable for me.

The goal is to create the best city possible by combining three of the same piece - three small houses make one bigger house, three bushes make a tree etc.

When all the spaces in your city have been filled, this part of the game ends and you can go back to this same area later on to try and better your score.

It's a fairly laid back game, although you do have some pretty angry bears trying to get in your way. There is one city area which is bear-free, meaning you can play without fear of being taken over by bears!

It's a nice, basic match-three game, and great for wasting a few hours here and there.

[h1][b]Game Visual/Audio[/b][/h1]

There isn't much can be said about the game's visuals asides from that they're well done. Pretty much the same thing can be said about the game's audio. The visual and audio can be adjusted in the game's option menu.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]

"Triple Town" is your typical match 3 game by Spry Fox. Instead of match like tokens to clear the board. The individual is tasked to match building structure and plant foliage to build a town from scratch. Most of the matches that are made is rewarded with  two or five coins. In most cases there are treasure chests with random resources.

The coins that are earned from the gameplay are used to make purchases in the main island area. The items are very expensive it will require the individual to save up enough coins to purchase that particular item. Since there is no option of selling off extra resources. Saving up coins can turn into a mundane task to complete.

The main island, building structures only available to make, they give out certain amount of resources for earning certain amount of points during gameplay. And their max upgrade is tier ten.

[h1][b]Miscellaneous[/b][/h1]

There are total of twelve different trading cards. You only get the six of those cards from the game. There are several ways to get the rest of the trading card: Purchased from Steam's Market; Trade with friends; Booster Packs and it's Booster Pack Creator.

Final thoughts, the game it's enjoyable to certain extent, even though it comes with a mundane task to complete. As for the game's replay value it's low. I would recommend this game but not at the full price.

20236294.review:
There's a tl;dr at the end for those who just want a quick synopsis.

Games like this make me wish Steam had a number system for reviews, like 1-10, instead of just positive or negative.  Because I do like this game but it does have some limitations which make it difficult to make a positive review.  Especially since this was originally a mobile phone game with microtransactions.  No, don't stop reading!  It's not as bad as the typical phone game ported to Steam.

From the screenshots you might think this is a typical match 3 casual game.  And it is, but not like Bejeweled or other games like that.  Triple Town is all about the strategy of placement.   The main playing field (there are several variations, not just one field) is a big grid with some items already placed.  Each turn you get an item like grass or bush and you have to place it somewhere on the grid.  When you place a grass next to two other grasses they instantly combine to form a bush.  Get three bushes together and they form a tree.  Three trees form a small red house.  Three red houses form a bigger house.  3 of those form a mansion.  3 mansions form a castle.  3 castles form a sky castle.  So you can see how you can quickly run out of room.  The items you get are not totally random, there must be a variable to give a greater chance for grass and bushes since you get those the most.  

You do get random items to help, like the blue crystal which acts like a wild card to instantly make a match of any 2 items you already have on the grid.  And you can buy items with the gold coins you get (this is where the microtransactions were in the mobile version).  Like buy a bush or tree for a few coins.  But I like to save my coins for the other part of the game: your town.

When you run out of room on the game field you go back to your town.  It's actually an island.  You build items here that use the same match 3 thing as the field but for buildings.  Like, 3 fields make a big field, 3 of those make a bale of wheat (or whatever it is), 3 of those make a store house, 3 of those make something else (I've forgotten).  There's farming, gold mining, and defense (cannons, towers, etc), Though you don't get attacked, it's just for show.  This is where I choose to use the coins I earn in the matching fields.  You can buy extra squares of land to add on to your island, extra matching items like fields or fences.  Or even a crane to move an item to a different location.  And once you're rolling in the dough (have lots of coins to spare) you can even buy decorations like letters, statues, and stuff like that to personalize your town.  

I'm sure by now you can imagine the microtransactions and how much money could be spent (wasted!) on stuff in this game.  Which brings me to my point in the beginning, why I hesitate to write a positive review.  Normally I am against microtransactions.  But I love the cute graphics in this game and the strategy involved.  The bears are especially cute and the way the villagers go "eek" and run when the bears growl.

tldr:

Ported mobile game that had microtransactions
Cute graphics
Deep strategy in placing items
Build your town, lots of personalization available
But it takes forever to get enough coins 
Get it on sale

20116941.review:
The 80 hours I have on record for this game is deceptive, because I'm lazy and have left it running on my computer constantly for 2-3 days this week, even when not playing. That said, I'd say that since buying it, I've probably sunk 10-15 hours into actually playing this game. I played for a good 5-10 hours after purchasing it two and a half years ago. Got caught up in a bunch of other games, and came back to it last week, determined to get the last 2 or 3 achievements, and put in at least another 5 hours.

That might seem like a lot for what deceptively looks like such a simple game, but the crux of the matter is as follows: 1) I was determined to beat it. For neurotic achievement hunter me, that meant, another perfect game. 2) It takes a lot of planning, like playing a chess game and trying to think a dozen moves ahead. I sometimes found a scratch pad and pencil helpful for planning things out. 3) The effing bears! And lastly, 4) This game is more than a little bit addictive. You tell yourself, nope, just going to finish this building and I'm done for the night. And some bear gets in the way of a building you've been working on for the past 5 minutes, and somehow, you've got a new game going because you know you can beat it this time.

I don't know that it's something that I would have shelled out $10 for. But I'm stingy like that. Having paid 3.99 for it, I find I'm okay with the price to time played/enjoyment ratio. The last couple of achievments are hard, but there's a pretty great guide in the community hub for it. In the end, I probably won't play this game again, or at least not any time soon, but I don't by any means regret the purchase.

18706545.review:
I do like this game, but with a disclaimer: I can only recommend it if you're not a completionist.

The pros: It's adorable beyond reason, it's light-hearted, amusing and easy to learn. It rewards you for getting better at it, with achievements and in-game rewards for scoring higher points. It makes you want to get good at it, because everything is easier: you get more points, more money, more assets and so forth. And sure, it's a Match 3 but you have an open grid to do whatever you want. Pretty neat. There are even little enemy bears (adorable mean fluffballs) to give you some amount of challenge.

The cons: It's likely never going to see another update again, so this is the final product - and it's kind of a small shell and a basic game. Is there a quirk of the gameplay you dislike? Too bad. My personal axe to grind, is that it takes wayyy too long to feel like you're making progress in the game. There's a little map you can customize as you earn more points: you build things, and those little buildings generate rewards and points for you. The map is its own ongoing mini-game, the actual 'objective' of Triple Town. It's a neat little system: if it didn't take a thousand years to earn enough money to buy and build anything. I'm at over 100 hours on this thing (don't judge me). I'd expect to be rolling in dough right now, but I'm lucky if I can save up to 10K before having to spend it on something for my little map. So sometimes this map's progress feels like watching paint dry.

It's a really cute game, though. If you don't get obsessive about these kinds of things, it's super cute to just pick it up for a few minutes at a time as you wish.

18392174.review:
Recommended, but best wait for a discount.

Triple Town is the Steam Version of a free mobile game with microtransactions- the buying price gives you the game WITHOUT the microtransactions, and the port is solid enough.

TT is a Match-3 game with a very elegant layout. On a 6x6 board, you lay out tiles that merge into a "better piece" when three or more same pieces are matched. Since you build a city, this means you upgrade grass to bushes, bushes to trees, and then merge those into more and more advanced houses. Positioning your pieces is crucial because the upgraded piece appear on the tile you made the match, and with the very small board, you're constantly fighting for space. As if this wasn't enough, occasionally wandering bears will appear- you match those for cathedrals. A variant, the ninja bear, is even more distracting as it teleports around the board, and it can never be matched.
A game ends when the board is filled, so each round is an attempt to beat your highest score- and earn resources for your "main city", which is a separate, larger map where you can match the earned resources into facilities and decorations.

As simple as the idea sounds (you match... grass), the game is pretty good! Once you've got the mechanics down, a round may well last a while before you succumb to bears or that One Bad Match. The "main city" is a nice addition, too, gicing you something larger to work for. You need special tiles to create the main city elements, wich are earned in the actual levels, or you can just spend some (in-game) money to buy your next upgrade... or something that gives you an edge during a level.

TT is not flashy. The music is minimal, the graphics are clean but rather functional, and apart from some "Simlish" mumble and bear growls you won't hear very much. It feels a bit barebones, really. You also only get four different board layouts, and since all game elements are revealed you don't have any reason to hunt for unlocks.

But the fun thing is, it doesn't matter. Triple Towns is a great idea in a very slim, clean package. It plays really well and that's all that matters for me.

For 10 Euros, TT is hard to recommend. There are more varied, more exiting, and more varied Match 3 games on Steam for that money.
But! Keep it on your wishlish, wait for a sale or daily deal- and then get it. You won't regret your purchase.

I don't really think of it as a "match 3" game, because even though you do match 3 things to create a better a thing that takes up less space so that you can create more bigger things, there is more strategy than luck involved, since you choose where to place each thing. It's simple to understand and get into, and I find it pretty soothing. I enjoy it, and at the same time, it's something I can sort of mindlessly play while I'm on the phone, or while I'm getting ready to go to sleep, etc. I'm not especially good at it, mind you, but I do enjoy it a lot. It's currently my go-to game when I'm not sure what I really want to do, and I wind up sticking with it longer than planned every time, but it's also fine for when I'm only going to have a very few minutes to play, because I can exit the game super quickly and it's saved automatically.

17729363.review: One of the few Match 3 games that has ever presented me with any real challange. Triple Town aims to reduce the role that luck plays on your game while emphasizing the importance of strategy. As you progress, you'll be forced to think several stages ahead. Say you're building a house; you should know where your last hut needs to go and plan backwards from there. Obviously this can get pretty complicated at the more advanced stages. There are some chaotic elements. Bears can quickly become a nuisance if you don't plan ahead for them. Ninja bears are even worse because they can't be contained like normal bears and can only be killed by filling all tiles on the map or by using a rare item on them. They're also the only thing that can really screw up your game even if you're playing well. There is a map without bears but you'll have fewer tiles to build on. This map is useful for getting the highest achievements. Overall, I highly recommend this. I think it's a must have for any fan of strategy and puzzle games. If I had one comlaint, it's that the Facebook version is (or was, I can't seem to find it anymore) prettier. I do wish they would update the graphics of the version I paid for to match the quality of the free version.

16524878.review:
[h1]Triple Town är ett spel som är roligt att spela, men som jag likväl inte kan rekommendera.[/h1]

Triple Town går ut på att försöka bygga så stora städer (byar) som möjligt och det gör man genom att matcha olika sorters föremål med varandra. Tre (eller fler) angräsande grästuvor blir till en buske, tre buskar blir till ett träd, tre träd blir till ett litet hus, tre hus blir till ett större hus och så vidare.
Den biten av spelet är riktigt kul och det gäller att tänka strategiskt annars har man snabbt skapat problem för sig själv som kan vara svårt att ta sig ur.

Problemet med spelet blir dock det metaspel som är inkluderat, men som inte är särskilt genomtänkt. När du bygger städer skapar du samtidigt guld (och andra råvaror) som är tänkta att hjälpa dig att bygga din huvudstad. (Du kan räkna med att tjäna ungefär 150-300 guldmynt per tio minuters speltid.)
Huvudstadsbyggandet följer samma princip som bybyggandet. Du börjar med nivå 1-föremål för militärt bruk, industrier och bondgårdar. Lyckas du matcha ex tre bondgårdar får du en ny bondgård på nivå 2 osv.
Det finns även hyfsat gott om föremål som bara är till för dekorativt syfte.
Egentligen är den här biten av spelet också kul, men de begränsningar som finns gör en mest frustrerad. 

Spry Fox har valt att inte ha IAP i Steam-versionen av spelet och istället ta lite mer betalt för det. Det tycker jag är av godo. Problemet är bara att IAP-mekaniken finns där. I många andra spel kan du välja att antingen betala en liten slant eller grinda under en lång tid för att få det du vill ha. 
För spel som saknar IAP vore det [i]rimligt[/i] att grinda under en rimligt lång tid, men tyvärr är så inte fallet här. 

Du börjar med en ö som består av 5 * 5 block. (Jag tror åtminstone att det är startstorleken.)
Du kan bygga ut ön genom att placera ut nya block och det är också här problemen börjar. Ett enda nytt block kostar 4 500 guldmynt. Du kan även köpa fem på samma gång för 20 000 guldmynt. Enbart för fem nya tomma block kommer du alltså att behöva sitta och grinda åtskilliga timmar.

Inser du att du har placerat ett föremål på fel ställe? Inga problem, det kan lyftkranen fixa. Pris: 1 200 guldmynt per flytt.

Tycker du att din huvudstad behöver en dekorativ fyr vid kusten? Det ordnar vi för den låga summan av 5 000 guldmynt.

Priserna i spelshoppen skulle behöva sjunka rätt rejält för att det ska bli rimligt, alternativt skulle inkomsterna behöva öka avsevärt.

Om du struntar fullständigt i huvudstadsbyggandet och bara vill bygga lite byar så kan jag absolut rekommendera Triple Town. Fast om du faktiskt vill spela hela spelet så kan jag tyvärr inte rekommendera det.

16519934.review:
[table]
    [tr]
        [td][h1]You'll Enjoy This Game If You Like:[/h1][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]"Just one more turn" games[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Ruthlessly murdering bears[/td]
        [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Thinking multiple steps ahead[/td]
     [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Mobile gaming[/td]
     [/tr]
[/table]

I was first exposed to Triple Town as a mobile game on the iPhone where I must have racked up an ungodly amount of hours. It really is one of those one more turn games - easy to pick up from where you left off and leaves you with an overwhelming desire to beat your best score.

It is a match 3 game at it's core, but with a very clever aspect to it. You match 3 building blocks to create a single block that is "one up". For example combine 3 grass tiles to make a bush and then combine 3 bushes to make a tree and so on. There is also the added difficulty of bears spawning on your grid which, put simply you need to kill. That's right, a cutesy game where you need to block in animals, which converts them to gravestones, which, staying with the theme of the game can be combined into a church.

The only downside of this game is that it is probably more suited to a mobile platform as a bit of the "pick up and play" aspect is lost on PC. That's not to say that you won't sink hours into it, just simply that your gaming sessions will likely be a bit longer (which is no bad thing) and you won't be sat on the toilet as you match 3.

Definitely a game I'd recommend but watch out for the ninja bears.

15070974.review:
Cutesy art, simple mechanics, and its origins as a mobile title will lull people into thinking this is an easy game.  And while it may be easy to play, it is incredibly hard to net high scores in the game.

You have a basic grid on which a randomized series of items are situated, the items you place are randomized.  You must link together at least three items of a kind in a vertical or horizontal chain, these chains can zig-zag and connect together a great many items, merging them into the next item up in quality of the same item base.  The three base unit types you have are Rocks, Bears, and Plants.  These three base units cannot be merged together, this leads to a conflict in placing each item as you must try to set up future placements without any foreknowledge of items to come,

The puzzle element itself is enjoyable and challenging, it will function as an enjoyable time sink if you let it.  There is also an external element of resource collection and island build up.  This is all to obtain game altering items which can allow you to place whatever you need whenever you need it in a pinch - generally not worth doing until you have a great many of them and are going to attempt a long game.

It is fun, but it is frustrating how you can often end up with a string of items you don't want which will end up killing you.

14588502.review:
I actually like the puzzle mechanic, and it's fairly satisfying to play and try to get better at it. I can understand why people like it and it got so popular. However, even though the PC version has no microtransactions (praise Gaben), the free-to-play roots still show through in the structure of the game, and it's worse for it. In a puzzle game based on skill, where your goal is to see how long you can survive/how far you can progress/how many points you can score in a single run, having an inventory of items you can (literally) farm that carry over between runs feels...dirty.

Unless you want to play a self-enforced challenge of willfully ignoring that part of the game, the optimal strategy is not to have the most skill at the game (or at least not JUST to have the most skill), but to spend x number of hours grinding to fill your inventory, THEN to wait until you're having a good run and burn through all your items to keep it going as long as possible. Want to try again? Waste another day. Why does this make the game better? It doesn't, because they're not making any money off you in this version. It's the taint of something that was originally designed to be a money siphon and not to play off its strengths, which it does have plenty of in terms of good design.

It's like if someone came up with Tetris today, and you could win spare pieces after each game you play if you do well, which you could stock up on. It would completely change the flow of the game from, "Gee, I did pretty well. I bet I can do better next time!" to, "Dang it. I just blew through all my straight pieces. Now I have to spend four hours farming more of them if I'm ever going to get a score like that again." And some asshole would let you buy more for 10 cents each or 12 for a dollar, just so you could always have one to swap into your "next" slot when you really needed it. I bet there's already a mobile or Facebook version like that out there somewhere. Now I'm sad.

14376839.review:
Triple Town is a puzzle game, where you place things on a grid, hoping to match three of the same object in order to upgrade it. I'd compare it to the puzzle game 2048 most... matching things collapses them, and the goal is match as many things as possible until you run out of space. 

Triple Town is a fairly good time-waster, and it takes a decent amount of strategy to not box yourself in, especially when you get an unexpected item to place. The custom island that serves as Triple Town's endgame, however, is fairly boring and it won't convince you to play the game any longer. The achievements make for much better goals... I'm still trying to get the highest level of castle.

The graphics are crisp and look very good. The sound is minimal with no background music. The control works fine. This is a game that was clearly designed for a mobile free-to-play model. It's nice to see that this game doesn't have microtransactions on top of the $10 price tag.

This is a fun little puzzle game, and was entertaining for a while, but after ten hours of playing, I don't think I feel like devoting much more time to it. Ten dollars seems excessive for this game, but it's probably worth it at $5.

13347715.review:
Le principe de Triple Town est très simple : posez des éléments sur un plateau d'une quarantaine de cases et groupez-les par 3 (ou plus) pour obtenir l'élément de niveau suivant. Exemple : 3 touffes d'herbe font un buisson, 3 buissons font un arbre, 3 arbres font une petite maison, etc.
Parfois, des ours viendront envahir le plateau et vous empêcheront de poser les éléments où vous le souhaitez. Il faudra donc s'occuper d'eux, et les grouper également.
Chaque élément posé ou assemblé rapporte des points. L'objectif est de faire le score le plus élevé possible. La partie s'arrête lorsque votre plateau est plein et que vous ne pouvez plus rien y placer. Vos points vous débloquent des éléments à assembler sur votre île : une petite parcelle de terrain persistante sur laquelle vous construisez un peu ce que vous voulez / pouvez.

La stratégie du jeu réside donc dans le placement des éléments : comment faire pour ne jamais se retrouver bloqué ?

Plusieurs types de partie sont disponibles : la quantité d'ours importuns et la structure du terrain varieront légèrement d'un type à l'autre.

Au premier abord, ce jeu est plutôt sympathique : les graphismes enfantins mignons, les petits personnages qui commencent à se promener sur le plateau quand vous avez quelques maisons, etc. L'ambiance est attirante.
Le principe du jeu, loin d'être révolutionnaire, est intéressant pour les gens qui aiment bien se creuser un peu la tête (mais pas trop quand même). Une partie est plutôt rapide (selon votre niveau bien sûr...), ce qui permet de faire des parties occasionnelles, quand vous avez 15 min à perdre.

Le gros point noir du jeu d'après moi : la durée de vie.
Malgré les quelques succès qui permettent d'avoir des objectifs et le mini "chez soi" à personnaliser, le jeu devient très vite répétitif. Une fois qu'on a fait les 4 ou 5 types de parties une dizaine de fois chacune, on commence à avoir fait un peu le tour... On s'aperçoit rapidement que les éléments intéressants à placer sur l'île perso nous coûteront de très nombreuses heures de jeu. La différence entre les types de partie pourrait être plus marquée. 
Bref, même sans y jouer souvent, on s'en lasse assez vite. Et on renonce à avoir une belle île avec un grand château et des décorations partout...

Pour résumer, TripleTown est un jeu plutôt attrayant à découvrir, pour ceux qui aiment les mini-jeux de ce genre (jeux de tableau "de réflexion"). Si vous avez quelques heures à tuer et que le jeu est en solde, je vous le recommande ! 
Par contre, si vous cherchez un jeu pas trop cher pour occuper vos longues soirées d'hiver pendant plusieurs mois, reportez votre choix sur un autre jeu :)

Match3パズルゲーム。
ブロックを設置して同じブロックを3つ以上並べて消すというMatch3パズルであるが、このゲームでは並べた全てのブロックが消えずに1つだけアップグレードされて上位ブロックとして残る。残ったブロックも同じブロックであれば消すことができ、さらに上位のブロックが残る。ブロックの設置場所に限りがあることと消した後に残るブロックを消すことも考えなければならない。シンプルで奥深い通常のMatch3パズルに独自のルールが追加されているユニークなパズルゲームだ。

お邪魔キャラとして熊が出てくる。このキャラは勝手に動き回りブロックの設置を邪魔する役割を持っている。熊の周りにブロックを置いて囲んでしまえば、熊は消えるが墓ブロックが残る。この墓ブロックも3つ並べて他のブロックに変えることができる。この熊以外にアイテムでしか消せない忍者熊も出てくる。

また、このパズルをプレイするごとに金と資材が手に入り、パズルをクリアするのに有効なアイテムを買ったりやホームタウンを発展させたりすることができる。ホームタウンもまたパズルになっており、同じブロックを3つ以上並べて発展させていく。発展すると発展させた施設からアイテム等が手に入る。発展させるだけでなくデコレートすることも可能だ。

残念なのは、ハイスコアを目指すためには金を稼いでアイテムを買って使わないといけないことだ。しかし、パズル自体はテンポ良く遊べる素晴らしいものだ。

12451008.review: Головоломка с элементами стратегии. На некоем континенте мы посылаем корабли дабы построить колонию. Есть стандартная колония - большая, с медведями и медведями ниндзя (медведи которые скачут с клетки на клетку), есть остров с медведями, но без ниндзя, есть вообще без медведей с маленькой картой. Принцип таков собираем три травы (или больше за это бонус) получаем куст, собираем три куста получаем дерево, три дерева - домик, три домика - коттедж, три коттеджа – замок, три замка – воздушный замок. Всё это время нам рандомно падают предметы трава, кусты, иногда деревья и кристаллы, кристаллами можно объединить любые два распложённых предмета одного типа, например два домика плюс кристалл получаем коттедж. Нам на картах с медведями постоянно мешают медведи, они также выпадают как и предметы, их нужно ставить на поле, три и больше медведя загнанные в ловушку дают часовню, три часовни получаем собор, три собора и выпадает сокровище из сундука. Ещё иногда выпадает возможность убрать ненужный предмет с карты, например камень. Как только все клетки на карте будут заняты произойдет подсчёт денег и ресурсов. Ресурсы можно тратить на континенте, там уже своя иерархия, но принцип тот же, поля дают пшеницу, камни – бочки с камнями, поленья дают забор, то есть тоже самое развитие по три предмета в сумме дают более развитое хозяйство, со временем таким крафтом можно строить здания которые будут давать ресурсы уже для колоний. Здесь на материке не работают кристаллы, но есть кран который помогает собирать и передвигать предметы для очистки поля так как места довольно таки мало. Фактически вся сумма с побед может уходить на приобретение крана для развития континента. Здесь есть магазин с огромными ценами где продаются кристаллы, деревья, кусты, трава, домики, возможность получить сокровище, очистить клетку, либо ящики для хранения предметов, для континента есть украшения и клетки позволяющие расширить континент. Один клочок земли обойдется в четыре с поливной тысячи, это очень дорого поскольку в среднем за игру на одном острове можно набрать шестьсот монет либо если хорошо играть побольше, как правило на сумму равную крану. Ключ к успеху планирование своих действий, заранее как в шахматах, на карте с медведями главная задача контролировать медведей поскольку плодятся они с бешеной скоростью. После того как вы построите воздушный замок без вложения средств становиться играть менее интересно, поскольку построить тройной воздушный замок не просто, нужна довольно таки большая сумма примерно десять тысяч монет и безупречная стратегия. Игра на мой взгляд более подойдет для женской аудитории либо тем, кто увлекается не сложными головоломками либо стратегиями. Игра для тех кто хочет отдохнуть несколько минут за весёлым и забавным крафтингом.

12242934.review:
The basic principle of Triple Town is nice, you have a limited area and have to put three objects of the same kind next to each other to create a single upgraded version of those objects, that can again be upgraded by putting two more objects of the same type next to it - and so on. This can become quite tricky the more items you have on a map since once you run out of space to place objects the level is over. When you upgrade an object you get points for it, naturally the more advanced an upgrade is, the more points you get. You can use those points to upgrade your town, which is the hub from where you access the randomly generated levels. The town's buildings generate items that will help you during the regular levels. The bigger and better your town becomes, the more and better items you will get.

The problem with the game is that there is no goal. No special challenges, nothing to achieve other than endlessly upgrading your town. It's the same thing over and over, and that felt rather pointless to me. You could try to get the best possible upgrade of an object (there is even a Steam achievement for it), but for that you need a lot of special items, and you can only obtain those by upgrading your town and collecting more money. That means you need to grind for dozens, if not hundreds of hours and all you get for it is a Steam achievement.

Imo this would be a decent time killer for mobile platforms, but there are simply far better puzzle games on PC to waste your time with Triple Town.

12143797.review:
[h1]Schöner Zeitvertreib mit Suchtfaktor[/h1]
Triple Town ist ein Kombinationsspiel mit einfach zu verstehender Spielmechanik: Platziere auf einem 6x6 Teile grossen Feld Gegenstände so, dass 3 gleiche aneinander angrenzen, um so aus den 3 Gegenständen 1 weiterentwickelten Gegenstand zu schaffen (z.B. 3 Gräser ergeben 1 Busch, 3 Büsche 1 Baum, 3 Bäume eine Hütte, etc). Was zunächst einfach klingt, entpuppt sich jedoch schon bald weitaus schwieriger als gedacht, da zum einen die Karte nicht unbegrenzt Platz bietet, zum anderen wilde (und knuddelige) Bären das Dorf unsicher machen, und so zusätzlich Platz wegnehmen und durch ihre bewegung Felder blockieren.
Das Spiel ist gut produziert, wobei mir die Mobile Version (auf Android) noch etwas besser gefällt, da sie sich auf das Kernthema des Spiels konzentriert. Die Steam-Fassung wurde um ein zentrales "Hauptstadt" Thema erweitert, welches sich aber nur mittelmässig ins Spielgeschehen einfügt und etwas deplaziert wirkt. Die Grafik ist durchweg knuddelig-süß, und auch nach längeren Sessions kann man dem erbauten Pixeldorf noch etwas abgewinnen.
Das Spiel hat absolutes Suchtpotential, und aus "mal eben 5 Minuten" wird schnell 1 Stunde oder mehr. Für Liebhaber von Kombinationsspielen absolut empfehlenswert, sowohl Einsteiger als auch Fortgeschrittene werden hier ihren Spaß haben!

12115465.review:
Portage PC repensé d'un jeu facebook freemium, Triple Town est un de ces jeux dans lequel on combine des trio de choses pour les faire grossir au sein d'un tableau plus ou moins carré. Le portage n'ajoute pas grand chose, à part enlever le modèle freemium avec achat de crédits pour jouer, et on sent très clairement qu'on est en présence d'un de ces jeux flashs qui consomment les après-midis des mères au foyer qui s'ennuient sur internet. L'ensemble est plutôt propre, rien à dire, le gameplay est basique et l'objectif du jeu reste plus dans la course au score qu'ailleurs. Entre les parties, on dispose d'une base dans laquelle on peut ajouter des batiments et les upgrader selon le même principe de trio, et décorer son jardin avec des lettres et des décors pour "faire joli" (encore un reste inutile témoignant des origines sociales du jeu). 
Au fur et à mesure des parties on engrange de la monnaie qui peut être utilisée pour acheter des objets à utilisation unique facilitant grandement certains passages dans les parties, exit donc l'idée de faire des high scores au skill uniquement, en farmant suffisament longtemps on peut se permettre d'acheter tout un tas de bonus temporaires pour faire une "super" partie. 
Ce n'est pas un mauvais puzzle en soit, ça reste plus intéressant que 2048 par exemple, mais au prix public c'est un peu douloureux pour les fesses, et terriblement répétitif. Les devs ayant qui plus est l'honnêteté d'avouer que le jeu est un échec sur PC (tu m'étonnes) et que les features ajoutées au jeu facebook ne seront probablement jamais transférées dans la version standalone car ce ne serait pas rentable, autant de points qui ne favorisent pas vraiment l'investissement, et on préfèrera s'orienter vers d'autres puzzle games moins handicapés par leur passé de freemium mal transformé.

12042170.review:
Ilmaisesta pähkinästä maksullinen säkki.

Suurin kysymys mikä monilla tämän pelin kanssa toimineilla herää ensimmäisenä mieleen sen kauppasivulle astuessaan, on se, miksi ilmaista selain- / mobiilipeliä myydään kymmenellä eurolla. Tavallaan ymmärrän sen mikä tässä maksaa, mutta hinta saattaa silti olla kova kolaus sille, paljonko peliä loppujen lopuksi ostetaan. Itse hankin pelin hyvin alennettuun hintaan, muut tekevät takuulla samoin tai ostavat sen siinä toivossa että se tarjoaisi enemmän kuin nämä ilmaisversiot.

Mikromaksut ovat tämän teoksen ostaneille historiaa, mikä on pelkästään plussaa. Toki se nopeuttaa etenemistä, mutta ajatuskin siitä että kuluttajat saavat nauttia pelin tarjoamasta sisällöstä täysin rinnoin vain jos kehittäjän kassavirtaan tiputellaan kourallinen valuuttaa, puistattaa niin että harkitsen ennemmin Electronic Arts -yhtiön DLC-kauppaa. 


[h1]Päätetään muistelmat...[/h1]

Triple Town ajaa asiansa tietynlaisena kylänkehitys-simulaattorina, lykäten peliin kuitenkin reilusti aivonystyröitä hierovaa strategista kulmaa. Kolmen sääntö toimi PopCapin timanttipelissä, ja toimii se piruvie myös tässä! Rajallinen pelilauta automaattisesti generoiduilla aloitusresursseilla, sattumanvaraisesti käteen osuvat kehityspalikat ja tavoitteena pistemäärän kasvatus. 

Kolmesta heinikosta tulee pensas, kolmesta pensaasta puu, kolmesta puusta saadaan tarpeeksi materiaa taloon, josta sitten siirrytäänkin jo luksustason variaatioihin. Kaupunkia voi kehittää halutessaan hyvinkin nopeatempoisesti, tai todella hitaasti, sillä ainoa raja on tila, joka on mitä luultavammin rajattu loppumaan jossakin pisteessä. Tähän pisteeseen päästäkseen tarvitsee jo todella käyttää aikaa maatilkkujen yhdistelemiseen, tai sitten kuluttaa vaivalla kerätyt kultakolikot tyyriissä kaupassa, josta voit käytännössä ostaa mitä tahansa ja sijoittaa sen haluamallesi paikalle pelilaudalle. 

Yksittäisen mission jälkeen pääset kehittelemään globaalia valtakuntaasi, joka toimii myös samoilla periaatteilla kuin nämä missiot, ainoana erona on palikoiden erilaisuus ja se fakta, että tätä skenaariota ei voi hävitä laudan tullessa täyteen.

Kymmenen euron hintalapulla en tätä PC:lle sovellukseksi portattua palapeliä ostaisi, mutta vähintään 50 prosentin tarjoustarralla tästä voi saada paljon irti, ilman että kaduttaa. Kuvat puhuvat pelistä hyvin, se on juuri sitä miltä se näyttää, joten mikäli silmää miellyttää, niin ei muuta kuin ostoksille!

12037131.review:
This is just one of those fun little games where you can sit down during an evening, open it up and relax while playing. It isn't intense gameplay. It's very simple. Match three of one object to make another one. Match three of those. And so on.  Yet, the simplicity doesn't take anything away from the game. However, if you want a high enough score, you have to be strategic in your placements of every object. But if you just want to put things in random places and see what happens, it is possible to get through the game that way too. So if you really don't want to put any effort in, you don't have to.

Triple Town is designed in a way that makes it look a lot like many Facebook games that people get addicted to (or annoyed by). Yet, it separates itself from them because you are not compelled to fork out your hard earned cash to keep playing... because there are no in-game transactions, which makes it aces in my book.

What I really like most about the game in addition to the simplicity factor is the soundtrack. The sound of birds. It's like you're sitting out in the middle of a garden on a summer afternoon.

In short, if you want a game that requires minimal brain power (but rewards you if you put more in) that you can wind down while playing, give Triple Town a go. Just be careful. It's addictive.

12030628.review:
The bears are come to remind us that all is chaos. All will be left to the bears, and to the shrubs, as empires fall, each in its time.

It is a somnambulant and disquieting reality, this Triple Town. Unknowable Lovecraftian horrors await at every turn. Quake at your smallness! Madness slathers with hunger and claws at your door. Yes, in the gaping maw of madness lies your perdition.

Your perdition is Triple Town.

This seems impossible, you say. Impossible! But all things are possible through Triple Town. All that becomes impossible beneath the great and terrible gaze of Triple Town, all that shall not linger—cannot linger!—in this dismal, eternal city...

...is you.

You say that you have come to conquer and dismantle Triple Town. I tell you that your heroism is the buzzing of a gnat amid a tempest. I tell you that your endeavor is doomed before it has begun. I tell you, for I pity you, that your eternity is but the blink of an eye to Triple Town. Therefore tremble, and depart.

Depart, while there still is life in you, though your retreat, like your bravery, means nothing. Triple Town will find you, wherever you may run. And should you live a thousand thousand lifetimes, your happiness will turn to ash as you hear the bears approaching, their growls crisp and icy and immutable.

And then, darkness.


8/10

11406574.review:
Игра с очень прилипчивым геймплеем. Начинаешь играть, чтобы попробовать, а тебя увлекает в поиски "когда же это всё закончится,  и чем". Собери три элемента в один, можно углом, и получи новый, более крутой. 
Игра построена в колонизационном стиле. Плывешь на один из четырех предложенных островов, и собираешь на нем, как можешь, из травы, кустов и деревьев - дома, здания и если удастся, замки. Тебе мешают МЕДВЕДИ- Тедди! Ужас...
Получаешь за это денежки и некоторые предметы. Переходишь обратно на свой базовый остров и опять собираешь из определенных элементов другие продвинутые элементы.
Есть три ветви предметов: сельскохозяйственная, милитаристская и промышленная. И есть просто украшательства, которые можно купить за заработанные монеты-денежки.

Короче элементы "три в одном" паззлов квестов. 

Недостатки: Никакого сюжета, а жаль. Мне показалось немного дорогой несбалансированной покупка всяких нужных предметов, по крайней мере первые 50 часов. потом набиваешь руку... и всё по барабану.
"Кэнди" или леденцовый дизайн предметов и всяких бегающих человечков.
Можно порекомендовать любителям паззлов-квестов, остальным следует игру избегать, ибо нефиг, увлекает.
За почти 100 часов я так и не понял чем всё заканчивается. Будет Win или нет.

10689115.review:
Triple Town is a game I've gotten a lot of value and fun out of, so the short answer is: yes, I would recommend this game.

There is something oddly addictive and yet very relaxing about playing this game. It is simple match three turn-based game, but the last item you place becomes the next tier up. So three bushes = 1 tree, 3 trees = 1 house, so on and so forth. It becomes a game about managing the precious space you have, and there is something very satisfactory and rewarding about putting in that one last piece and watching your board transform into a new thing you haven't seen before.
Except the elusive Triple Castle. Curse you! I always lose before I get to that stage.

So, there are several maps to the game. There’s the main town, were the buildings you place give you resources for the other maps - little extra things you can place down to match three when you're in a tight spot. Then there are a few maps with different flavours - one where there are lots of aggressive bears who walk around and get in the way of your plans, smaller maps with no bears where you can test your building skills. It's nice to be able to switch between them when you get stuck, and also nice to pop into your town and see what's up there.

You also gain currency when you 'complete' a map which can go towards buying things to help you in future runs, so that's pretty cool.

All in all a deceptively cute casual game that can be a little hard at times. If you're looking to play something relaxing when you have a little down time, this is perhaps my favourite puzzle game to recommend. It's very much like Combine or 2048 but more in-depth, lovable, and appealing to the eye.

An astoundingly addictive tile laying match game.  Very clean art design, great thematic flavour all added in with "just one more round" gameplay.  The dual layered nature of the game with your home island (persistant and generates resources for use in the colony games and building the main island) and with the colony games (the main tile laying match puzzle strategy portion) leads to a much greater depth of play than is first apparent.

Yes, in the beginning the rewards seem paltry compared to the prices at the store.  However, I found that with proper planning you will use very little of the items in the store.  On your home island you will most often use the crane to move a mistakenly places merged level 3 or 4 tile.  Get to planning ahead to avoid this!  Save the 20K gold for the 5 tile expansion.  

Do not be afraid to spend gold on the colony boards!!  Bushes are cheap at 150 gold and get you out of a pile of trouble.  Trees are a steal at 400 and can turn an average score into a mega score.

Spend some relaxing fun time discovering all this game has to offer, stretch your brain and enjoy!

9/10

9371176.review:
Triple Town is a port of a Facebook/Mobile game. It's a match 3 game where you have the goal of building a small settlement in a new land. Other than that there's not much more story to speak of. You can play for a few minutes or an hour, however long you like. 

Being a port of a Facebook/Mobile game, my first fear was that it would retain certain freemium or free 2 play features like grinding or paying for in-game currency. This fear really doesn't hold and I found myself really enjoying this small joyful timewaister.

It's a match three game. So say you start off by matching three Grass pieces together, which forms a bush. If you then get three bushes together it forms into a tree, three trees into a house, three houses into a town hall and so on. If you combine more than three you gain bonus points and a chance or higher chance for a structure for your hub world. Placement takes place on a grid system, the main antagonists being rocks, water and bears. Rocks can be removed by an item you can be given a turn like you can be given a grass or a bush or a tree. Water is there to stay and bears will hop to open spaces adjacent to them each turn and turn into tombstones when there are no open spaces for them to migrate to. Three tombstones turns into a church, three churches to a chapel, I think you get the idea!

Making matches and completing levels/settlements earns you coins. Coins can be used to buy items to be used in levels or in your hub world. The hub world follows the same rules as the levels. You gain resources that you place, match three and they become a better version of that resource. You use the hub world to embark on different level types like levels without bears or without water. The hubworld also allows you to personalize it a little. It's clear on the facebook and mobile versions this is where it would cost you actual money, but here it is just based on your actual progress, not income. And it is not necessary or made in a way where you are forced to grind.

Triple Town is not completely devoid of strategy, letting you save at least one "piece" for later use, allowing special items that remove rocks or other structures on the level. But This never gets stressful with its adorable art style. It can be as casual or as in depth as you want, with the only limiter being the luck of the draw each turn and how far you plan ahead.

If you want an adorable, uplifting time-relief, you can't find a much better game than this. I've normally played this before heading out somewhere, played this on my laptop, played while I was downloading something or while watching TV.

7845129.review:
Triple Town makes an excellent first impression. It’s a unique take on the match-3 genre that also gives it a colony/city building twist (only in flavour, though. It plays nothing like a city simulation). The graphics are super-ultra-kawaii-cutie-koochy-koochy-boo-boo. And while it has no music, Triple Town is also host to mega-adorable sound effects: bears make little grunts and citizens will come out of their buildings to talk gibberish with each other.

On Mobiles, these great impressions don’t last. On those platforms, the game advertises itself as free-to-play, but is actually not. If you want to play more than a limited number of turns per day, you have to pay a one-time fee of about $4. Triple Town developers have also devised other means to suck your money, by selling in-game currency, or cosmetic improvements. For what is ultimately a simple match-3 game disguised as free-to-play entertainment, the bill can therefore quickly inflate. Especially as the game is designed to make you want to trade your real cash against the in-game currency. 

For you see, the in-game currency you earn at the end of a session, or from your meta-game buildings, is incredibly small when compared to the costs of the items from the in-game shop. It can literally take several hours before you can buy anything remotely useful.

On PC, where the game will cost you money upfront ($10, outside of sales), you of course get unlimited turns from the start, and there is no built-in real money micro-transaction. That doesn't mean that you get everything the mobile version has to offer against your initial investment. Oooh no… Instead, many things are forever out of your reach: no cosmetic upgrade and no graphical themes for you! And you’d be wrong to think that the absence of real-money micro-transaction means a better balance between rewards and item costs.

I know that all those optional extras (graphical themes, in-game shop…) can be ignored, no matter how distastefully they serve the developer’s business model. But the fact is that the core game quickly shows its limits too. There is just not enough variety to sustain lasting fun. Game after game, you’ll be doing the same things with the same elements. Getting better only means that a game lasts more turns, not that you reach a further stage. There are several levels to select at the start of the game, but the difference is limited to the size of the starting grid or the frequency of bear appearances. Depending on your tolerance for repetitiveness, Triple Town will start feeling tiresome after two to five hours.

Conclusion: Triple Town is built on a promising twist of the match-3 formula, with limited but cute audio-visual assets. Its mechanisms are however too limited to provide lasting appeal. Add to that a misleading and greedy micro-transaction scheme on the mobile versions, or limitations to the PC version features, and you get a casual game that is very hard to recommend. There are many match-3 games on the market that are polished, provide variety and are honest about how they want your money, like “Bejeweled 3” and “4 Elements”, to name just a few. You should play those instead.

7771381.review: Triple Town has been around for a while. I first stumbled upon this game via Android, during a more basic age for Triple Town. Now, in the desktop version, you're faced with additional modes inclluding city management and new "arenas." The idea is simple, connect three of the same type of object to upgrade them into one new one. Connect three of the new objects to upgrade those into yet another upgraded object. And.. Continue. In the meantime, terrible bears and ninja bears appear to block your open tiles, as they move between each of your object placements. To remove them? Trip them inside your objects to them into gravestones. Guess what- Connect three gravestones and you get a church, and upgrade those, too! No Triple Town experience is ever the same, and if you're a fan of puzzle games, this game definitely screams for your attention.

7768631.review:
Blatantly an iOS game with little done to remodel the UI, but despite feeling like I should be playing this on a phone the game is surprisingly addictive. Gameplay consists of dropping down items on a playing field to build up match-3 combos and get bigger and bigger chunks of points. Good combos can be rewarded with items to use in the overworld, where you again match things to get combos and build more and more...for no reason other than to do it, really. Like I said, blatantly an iOS game designed to addict you into doing things and dropping money to make doing that easier, though the PC port features no microtransactions.

The game also features a few presets of modifiers like field size, lakes, and the presence of types of bears (which try to block you from placing blocks but can be trapped and combined to make large amounts of points) to mix things up, though I feel it would be much more fun to have control over each individual modifier as well and build your own custom game types. Overall I enjoyed it, though I think it'd be a stretch to call it a good game. Pick it up for 75% off sometime and you can probably get your money's worth out of it.

熊とたわむれるパズルゲーム。
基本的にはタイトル通り（？）草を3つ集めて茂みにして、茂みを3つ集めて木にして、木を3つ集めて小屋にして、小屋を3つ集めて……という感じで、同じオブジェを3つ集めて次ランクのオブジェにアップグレードという作業を繰り返して得点を稼ぐゲーム。

特色としてはオブジェのランクが9つもあり（草→茂み→木→小屋→家→豪邸→城→浮遊城→トリプル浮遊城）、それぞれの段階ごとに3つ集めなければならないため、場に余計なオブジェがどんどん増えていき、進めば進むほど作業の場が限られていくところ。それに加え、次ランクのオブジェは3つ目のオブジェを作った場所に生成されるので、上を狙えば狙うほど（具体的には豪邸→城あたりから）先の先を考えて配置していく必要が出てきて、見た目かわいい絵柄のくせになかなか頭を使わせられるゲームになっている。
一手一手進行していくタイプのゲームで時間制限の類がないので、次の一手をじっくり考えて打てるのも個人的な好みに合っていた。

欠点というか多少やり込んだ末にこれはどうかと思ったのは、ワイルドカードのクリスタルが便利すぎる上に結構な確率で配布されるので、オブジェを2つ揃えた時点で特に困らずアップグレードできたりするところ。
しかも必要な時は普通に即時購入できたりするので、最終的にはいかにクリスタルを節約して自力で3つ揃えるかみたいな本末転倒なゲームになってた感がある。

いまいち意味の分からないホームタウンの成長要素以外にはゲームの主目的が全くないのもアレなのだが、Steam実績マニアであればトリプル浮遊城を作るという最終目標が自動的に設定されるので、長考系パズル好きかつ実績好きなら楽しめるかと。
元はスマホ向けのゲームらしいし10ドルの価値があるかと問われると微妙なところだけど、安ければ暇つぶし兼頭の体操用に買ってみてもいいのでは。

3976646.review:
Triple Town is a match-three game paired with simplistic city building elements that requires more strategic thinking than games in this genre usually do.

The game is easy to learn and pretty hard to put away. The premise is simple: You start with a somewhat empty board, the "city", and then receive one component per turn, which you need to place on the board. Three of the same kind result in one piece of the next higher tier. For example, three bunches of grass give you a bush, and three (or more) bushes connected horizontally or vertically give you a tree.

The tricky part is that the resulting item appears in the spot where you put the previous item, and this is where the strategy originates from. Not only do you need to create matches on a small board, you also need to plan ahead so that future pieces fit together and you can upgrade to, say, a castle. Matching the highest tiers will grant you a treasure chest. with random loot.

Depending on the mode you play in (the game offers several with individual rulesets), there will also be bears. Bears wander around the board and turn into tombstones when you trap them. Three tombstones can be matched for a church (which does give you points) and three churches give you a cathedral. Building those is extra hard because the bears move around  and trapping them may require you to clutter the board.

To make it easier, you are given a storage spot where you can swap and keep one item, and there are special components such as the bot (that removes any item from the board) and the gem (which works like a joker). There is also a shop where you can purchase items and components with gold that you get by making larger matches. This is strictly in the game, there are no in-app purchases or DLC.

The other element of the game is your permanent capital city where you can place grain fields, military buildings, etc. which yield resources. These, too, can be matched and thus upgraded. If you play well, the game gives you rewards that can be put down in your capital.

Overall, Triple Town is a deeper-than-it-looks match-3 game that gets quite addictive (further made "worse" by there being achievements!). It's a friendly game that does not get stressful (it's all turn-based). Sadly, while the iOS version got ratings in the 80s and 90s, the identical PC version scored much lower. Different audiences, I guess.

I enjoy it, but I do like match-3 ganes, turn-based strategy and puzzlers. :)

3627541.review:
"Triple Town" is a unique Match 3 game where you build as big a colony town as possible by matching three or more objects. These objects can evolve into others by making appropriate matches (e.g. three Grasses make a Bush, three Bushes make a Tree...three Trees make a Hut...and there's more after that! ;-D). Matching more than three items, or mathcing certain high-end items will gift you different goodies that improve your score or other parts of the game! What you're given to place each time is random, but you can place these objects in any free space you want (with the objects melding where you place the last item in the cluster), so there's more strategy involved than the average Match 3.

Besides building materials, there are helpful items, like the Crystal, which is a wild card that completes matches (often important for much easier matching of high-end items!), but placing them without a Match makes a Boulder. Match three Boulders with the Crystals, however, and you'll get a Mountain that contains a Treasure Chest that contains a random prize. To get the Chest you need the Imperial Robot, which also lets you get rid of an unwanted item (most items penalize your score when destroyed, though...keep that in mind).

But watch out, there are Bears and Ninja Bears who'll try to impede your building! If you can trap a Bear or use an Imperial Robot on him, he turns into a Tombstone, and if you can trap three or more bears, the resulting Tombstones turn into a Church, and three of those make a Cathedral, and three of those make a Treasure Chest. Ninja Bears jump around and mostly can only be stopped by the Imperial Robot.

There are more items such as Fortune Cookies (which tell you the next five items that you'll be given to use), and Crates (which let you temporarily stash an item on the map), but these are gotten through the Shop and the Captiol City (more on those later!).

If you can't place something in a good spot right away, there's a little space set aside on each level where you can save an item, hopefully for a better use later in your game.

When you do run out of space (hopefully later rather than sooner!), your score is finalized, and you win some Coins and Capitol City materials (more on those in a bit!). If you need to stop playing a level, you can pick up where you left off later. There is no limit to how many times you can play a level; if you start a new level after finishing one, a new one is rolled for you!

There are six different kinds of levels: "Standard colony" (self-explainitory), "City on a lake" (actually, it's a "Standard colony" with a small lake in the center), "Peaceful Valley" (island with no Bears!), "A dangerous forest" (island with lots of Bears!), "City on an island" (small island). You can also revisit the Tutorials that you play the first time you launch the game, if you wish. You visit these from the Capitol City hub, which you build and improve mainly by making matches, too! You'll mainly get the materials from playing the game. The highest level buildings in your town will gift you materials and items everytime you earn so many points at a time in levels!

There is also a shop system that lets you buy building objects and helpful items with coins that you win in-game, mainly by completing levels. There are two different shops; one for the colonies, and one for the Capitol City. The colony shop lets you buy materials and items, but they're limited in supply, and replenish after so many turns. But if you've got the money, they can help you keep building for longer! The Capitol Shop lets you buy materials, Decorations, Expansion Tiles, and a Crane that lets you pick up and move an item to a better spot. These will cost you, though, so build some colonies!

There are personal High Score lists for each level, and 10 Achievements to earn. Recently, support for Steam's new Trading Card program has been added, too.

Overall, this is a great and different Match 3 game! Definitely check it out! :-D

5304719.review: TripleTown is a fun strategy/puzzle game in which you get random tiles to place that, when grouped in 3's, turn into the next rank of tile. Put 3 weeds together, you get a bush. Put 3 bushes together, you get a tree. Put 3 trees together, you get a house. Simple concept, yet there is a struggle to manage space on the board as well as the addition of bears that you place, but are mobile afterwards. These guys get in your way, invariably screwing up your best laid plans.. and not to mention the ninja bears, who blink around the board each turn. After the game finishes, you are rewarded with bonus tiles that you can play on your home island map (which plays with similar rules, but sans bears). I will probably not be explaining how fun this title is. There is a free version of this online on facebook if you want to get a taste of it. This version just eliminates the need to wait for turns to refresh or for the user to have to buy extra turns (which is annoying as the game is addictive). Well worth the $10 I spent on it.

3216435.review: I was really suprised by this title.  To me it's Bejeweled meets Chess.  You can't just match 3 mindlessly, you must plan ahead MANY turns in order to succeed. I won't go into much detail as you can just watch some youtube vids to see what I mean. But I will say it's very addictive as a single round type game, BUT you add in the meta game of building your own city with rewards from each match, which is in itself another puzzle type all together, and it's impossible to put down.  And it has ninja bears, you CANNOT go wrong with ninja bears.... ever...

811519.review:
Triple Town is an excellent match-3+ game with a small twist. Combine three bushes and they'll turn into a tree. Create and match three trees and it'll become a house and so on and so forth. It's all about the points and the coins. It's quite addictive, trust me.

The coins can be used to upgrade your hub, a place where you can pick a gameplay mode (sort of) before playing/ Or it can be used to buy items, like extra houses or bushes. Unfortunately, items are limited so you have to choose wisely. The items are also quite expensive, so buying an item isn't always a good choice.

The hub is all about creating farms, mines and other buildings. See it as some sort of mini-game. Except you can't really mess things up here. You'll be able to collect rewards from your buildings every couple of hours. Rewards that'll help you when playing the 'real' game. The developers haven't thought things through with the time limit though, because earning coins is kind of slow and tedious and waiting for several hours before being able to collect a reward could make people lose interest (more quickly than intended).
But I heard it might be changed in the near future, so let's just hope for the best.

Anyway, Triple Town is easily one of the my favorite casual games.

[Rating: 79/100]

2972596.review: Fun game if you've played it on your phones and you know how to play. Easy to pick up, hard to master. All in all an extremely addicting game if you're into a slightly different spin from standard Strategy games. 9/10, but not worth all of $10.

738648.review: So this game used to be free, but that version had all of the advertisments and that one mechanic where you could only do so many turns a day. but this is a new age. The developers have wiped all that away. This is the full game, none of that bad stuff exists in this one. It is entirely its own package worth paying for in full. Triple Town's simple and unique gameplay is just as addictive as it was on the mobile or facebook, but even better you get the whole game, The Capital City part makes you want to keep playing so you can keep adding onto it with every completed town. Triple Town on steam is hands-down one of the best indie casuals out there.
